body:
If you’ve been following Donald Trump’s presidential campaign over the past few months, you already know what’s in his book.

Repeated assurances that Mr. Trump is extremely wealthy and successful? Check. Trumpian infelicities of language? Check — “if you have laws that you don’t enforce,” Mr. Trump writes, “then you don’t have laws. This leads to lawlessness.” Complex issues of international relations and domestic policy discussed in terms of “winning” and “losing”? Check, ad nauseam.

In fact, what’s most surprising about Mr. Trump’s book, called “Crippled America: How to Make America Great Again” and released on Tuesday, is how few surprises it contains.

Mr. Trump is clearly pleased with his reputation for making shocking statements. “Sometimes,” he writes, “I make outrageous comments and give them what they want — viewers and readers — in order to make a point. I’m a businessman with a brand to sell.” And on the campaign trail, he has repeatedly cast his opponents as “low-energy.” The message: Other candidates are dull, but Donald Trump shakes it up with his unfiltered, take-no-prisoners style. Who knows what he’ll say next?

Actually, pretty much everyone knows. At this point, Mr. Trump is just as predictable as Jeb Bush, or any of the other candidates he’s criticized as not energetic enough to lead the country. He has one idea, and it’s a terrible one: Build a wall between the United States and Mexico and somehow force Mexico to pay for it. Beyond that, his book and his campaign consist mainly of boasts about his deal-making prowess, promises to solve complicated problems by asking some smart people about them (to develop a healthcare plan to replace Obamacare, he writes, “we should hire the most knowledgeable people in the world on this subject and lock them in a room — and not unlock the door until they’ve agreed on the steps we need to take”) and a few insults thrown in for good measure.

The pot shots and grandstanding that defined Mr. Trump at the beginning of his campaign weren’t evidence of an outside-the-box intellect at work, as some of his supporters claimed. They’re all Mr. Trump has, and like any other routine, they get tired over time. Can you think of something Mr. Trump could say that would actually shock you now? I can’t, except, “I am totally unqualified for the presidency.”

Mr. Trump has certainly been more openly xenophobic than some of his opponents (though a few have gamely risen to his level). But ultimately, he’s no more exciting than any of them — he’s just louder.
description: Mr. Trump is just as predictable as Jeb Bush, or any of the other candidates he’s criticized as not energetic enough to lead the country.
title: Taking Note: Donald Trump Is Boring
